Sub_topics.description: Describe and compare eukaryotic (plant and animal) cells and prokaryotic (bacterial) cells: eukaryotic cells have cell membrane, cytoplasm and genetic material enclosed in a nucleus; bacterial cells are much smaller, have cytoplasm and a cell membrane surrounded by a cell wall; genetic material not enclosed in a nucleus (single DNA loop) and may contain plasmids (small rings of DNA). Understand scale and size of cells; make order-of-magnitude calculations including standard form; use prefixes centi-, milli-, micro-, nano-.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Animal and plant cell organelles and functions
Sub_topics.description: Explain how main sub-cellular structures relate to function: nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, mitochondria, ribosomes; plant cells additionally often have chloroplasts and a permanent vacuole (cell sap); plant and algal cells also have a cellulose cell wall for strength; bacterial cells may have plasmids. Interpret/recognise/draw cell images; use estimations to judge relative size/area of sub-cellular structures.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Microscopy (plant and animal cells)
Sub_topics.description: Use a light microscope to observe, draw and label a selection of plant and animal cells; include a magnification scale. Skills: measure/record length/area appropriately; use appropriate magnification and produce labelled scientific drawings from biological specimens.

Given appropriate information, explain how the structure of different specialised cells relates to function in a tissue/organ/organ system/whole organism. Examples: animal sperm cells, nerve cells, muscle cells; plant root hair cells, xylem and phloem cells.

Explain the importance of cell differentiation: as organisms develop, cells differentiate to form different types; most animal cells differentiate early; many plant cells retain ability to differentiate throughout life. In mature animals, cell division mainly for repair/replacement. Differentiation involves acquiring different sub-cellular structures to carry out a particular function (specialised cell).

Understand how microscopy techniques have developed over time and how electron microscopy increased understanding of sub-cellular structures (limited to differences in magnification and resolution). Electron microscope has much higher magnification and resolving power than light microscope, enabling finer detail and more sub-cellular structures to be seen. Calculate magnification, real size and image size using: magnification = size of image / size of real object; express answers in standard form where appropriate; use centi-, milli-, micro-, nano- prefixes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Chromosomes, DNA and genes (cell division context)
Sub_topics.description: State that the nucleus contains chromosomes made of DNA molecules; each chromosome carries many genes; in body cells chromosomes are normally found in pairs. Use simple models/analogies to develop explanations of how cells divide.

Describe stages of the cell cycle including mitosis (no need for named mitotic phases): cell grows and increases sub-cellular structures (e.g., ribosomes, mitochondria); DNA replicates to form two copies of each chromosome; during mitosis one set of chromosomes is pulled to each end and nucleus divides; then cytoplasm and cell membranes divide to form two genetically identical cells. Explain importance of mitosis for growth and development in multicellular organisms; recognise/describe contexts where mitosis is occurring.

Define a stem cell as undifferentiated cell capable of producing more of same type and differentiating into other cells. Describe function of stem cells in embryos, adult bone marrow (e.g., blood cells), and plant meristems (can differentiate into any plant cell throughout life). Explain potential medical uses (e.g., diabetes, paralysis) and therapeutic cloning (embryo with same genes as patient; stem cells not rejected). Evaluate risks (e.g., viral infection transfer) and ethical/religious objections. Describe use of meristem stem cells for rapid/economic plant cloning, including conserving rare species and cloning crops with desired traits (e.g., disease resistance). Note: detailed stem cell techniques not required.

Define diffusion as net movement of particles from higher concentration to lower concentration in solution or gas; explain movement across cell membranes by diffusion. Examples: oxygen and carbon dioxide in gas exchange; urea moving from cells into blood plasma for excretion in kidneys. Explain factors affecting diffusion rate: concentration gradient, temperature, surface area of membrane. Explain why single-celled organisms have large surface area to volume ratio enabling sufficient exchange; calculate/compare surface area to volume ratios. Explain need for exchange surfaces and transport systems in multicellular organisms in terms of SA:V ratio; explain adaptations of small intestine and lungs in mammals, gills in fish, roots and leaves in plants. Describe features increasing effectiveness: large surface area, thin membrane/short diffusion path, (animals) efficient blood supply, (animals gas exchange) ventilation.

Define osmosis as diffusion of water from a dilute solution to a concentrated solution through a partially permeable membrane (across cell membranes). Use simple compound measures of rate of water uptake; use percentages; calculate percentage gain/loss of mass of plant tissue; plot/draw/interpret appropriate graphs for osmosis investigations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Osmosis in plant tissue
Sub_topics.description: Investigate effect of a range of concentrations of salt or sugar solutions on the mass of plant tissue. Measure mass change and time; determine % change; present data graphically; consider accuracy, repeats, and improvements.

Describe active transport as movement of substances against concentration gradient (from dilute to more concentrated) requiring energy from respiration. Explain role in uptake of mineral ions by root hairs from very dilute soil solutions (ions needed for healthy growth) and absorption of sugar molecules from lower concentration in gut to higher concentration in blood (for respiration). Compare diffusion, osmosis and active transport: direction relative to gradient, particles moved, and energy requirement; describe transport into and out of cells by all three processes.

Define and relate levels of biological organisation: cells as basic building blocks; tissues are groups of similar cells with similar structure/function; organs are aggregations of tissues performing specific functions; organ systems are groups of organs working together to form organisms. Understand size/scale relationships between cells, tissues, organs, systems.

Describe human digestive system as an organ system where several organs work together to digest and absorb food (assumes KS3 knowledge). Describe enzymes as biological catalysts: enzyme molecules, specificity due to active site shape; lock-and-key model as simplified explanation (other models may also be used). Relate enzyme activity to temperature and pH; carry out rate calculations for enzyme-controlled reactions. Recall sites of production and action of amylase, proteases and lipases. Explain digestion: enzymes convert food to small soluble molecules absorbed into bloodstream; carbohydrases break carbohydrates to simple sugars (amylase breaks down starch); proteases break proteins to amino acids; lipases break lipids to glycerol and fatty acids. Explain role of bile: made in liver, stored in gall bladder; alkaline to neutralise stomach HCl; emulsifies fat to increase surface area; alkaline conditions and increased surface area increase lipase rate. Understand simple word equations (no chemical symbol equations required here). Link products to building new carbohydrates, lipids, proteins; glucose used in respiration.

Use qualitative reagents to test for carbohydrates, lipids and proteins: Benedict’s test for sugars, iodine test for starch, Biuret reagent for protein (and associated safe heating/water bath/Bunsen use where required).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Effect of pH on amylase
Sub_topics.description: Investigate effect of pH on rate of reaction of amylase: continuous sampling to find time to completely digest starch at a range of pH values; iodine test for starch every 30 s; control temperature using water bath/electric heater. Record time data, calculate rates, graph activity vs pH, evaluate method and improvements.

Describe structure and functioning of human heart and lungs including how lungs are adapted for gas exchange. Heart as a double circulatory system: right ventricle pumps to lungs for gas exchange; left ventricle pumps to rest of body. Blood vessels associated with heart limited to: aorta, vena cava, pulmonary artery, pulmonary vein, coronary arteries; names of valves not required. Lung structures limited to: trachea, bronchi, alveoli and surrounding capillary network. Describe pacemaker: group of cells in right atrium controlling resting heart rate; artificial pacemakers correct irregularities. Describe three blood vessel types (arteries, veins, capillaries) and explain how structure relates to function. Use compound measures such as rate; carry out rate calculations for blood flow.

Describe blood as tissue of plasma with suspended red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets; know functions of each. Recognise different blood cells in photos/diagrams and explain adaptations to function. Consider risks related to use of blood products (evaluation context).

Explain coronary heart disease: fatty material builds up in coronary arteries narrowing them, reducing blood flow and oxygen to heart muscle. Describe stents to keep arteries open; statins reduce blood cholesterol slowing deposit. Describe faulty valves and consequences (may not open fully or may leak); replacement using biological or mechanical valves. Explain heart failure treatments: heart or heart-lung transplant; artificial hearts as temporary support or to allow recovery. Evaluate advantages/disadvantages of treating cardiovascular disease using drugs, mechanical devices, or transplant, considering risks and benefits.

Define health as state of physical and mental well-being. Distinguish communicable and non-communicable diseases as major causes of ill health; describe other factors (diet, stress, life situations) affecting health. Explain interactions between diseases: immune defects increase infectious disease risk; viruses can trigger cancers; immune reactions can trigger allergies (rashes, asthma); severe physical ill health can lead to depression and other mental illness. Translate disease incidence between graphical/numerical forms; construct/interpret frequency tables/diagrams, bar charts, histograms; use scatter diagrams to identify correlation between variables. Understand sampling principles for scientific/epidemiological data.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lifestyle factors and non-communicable disease risk
Sub_topics.description: Discuss human and financial costs of non-communicable diseases to individuals/communities/nations/globally. Explain effect of lifestyle factors (diet, alcohol, smoking) on incidence at local/national/global levels. Define risk factors (lifestyle aspects; substances in body/environment) and distinguish where causal mechanisms are proven vs not. Required examples: diet/smoking/exercise on cardiovascular disease; obesity as risk factor for Type 2 diabetes; alcohol effects on liver and brain function; smoking effects on lung disease and lung cancer; effects of smoking and alcohol on unborn babies; carcinogens including ionising radiation as cancer risk factors; many diseases due to interaction of multiple factors. Interpret data about risk factors; apply sampling principles; translate info between graphs/tables and numbers; identify correlations via scatter diagrams.

Describe cancer as result of changes in cells leading to uncontrolled growth and division. Distinguish benign tumours (contained, do not invade) vs malignant tumours (cancers) that invade tissues and spread in blood to form secondary tumours. Recognise that scientists have identified lifestyle risk factors for cancers and genetic risk factors for some cancers.

Explain how plant tissue structures relate to function: epidermal tissue, palisade mesophyll, spongy mesophyll, xylem, phloem, meristem tissue (growing tips). Leaf as organ: knowledge limited to epidermis, palisade and spongy mesophyll, xylem and phloem, and guard cells around stomata; observe/draw transverse leaf sections where provided.

Explain adaptations of root hair cells, xylem and phloem to functions. Describe transpiration and translocation; role/structure/function of stomata and guard cells in controlling gas exchange and water loss. Explain effect of temperature, humidity, air movement and light intensity on transpiration rate; use compound measures for transpiration rate; translate between graphs and numerical data; plot/draw appropriate graphs and interpret tables/charts. Describe root hair uptake: water by osmosis, mineral ions by active transport. Describe xylem as hollow tubes strengthened by lignin transporting water/mineral ions in transpiration stream. Describe phloem transporting dissolved sugars from leaves for use/storage (translocation); phloem as elongated cells with pores in end walls; detailed mechanism not required.

Explain how diseases caused by viruses, bacteria, protists and fungi are spread in animals and plants; explain how spread can be reduced or prevented. Define pathogens as microorganisms causing infectious disease; they may infect plants/animals and spread by direct contact, water or air. Describe that bacteria and viruses may reproduce rapidly in body; bacteria may produce toxins damaging tissues and causing illness; viruses live and reproduce inside cells causing cell damage.

Measles: symptoms fever and red skin rash; serious, can be fatal; vaccination of young children; spread by inhalation of droplets from sneezes/coughs. HIV: initial flu-like illness; unless controlled with antiretroviral drugs attacks immune cells; late stage AIDS when immune system badly damaged leading to inability to deal with infections/cancers; spread by sexual contact or exchange of body fluids (e.g., shared needles). Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV): plant pathogen (e.g., tomatoes) causing mosaic discolouration on leaves, reducing photosynthesis and growth.

Salmonella food poisoning: spread by bacteria in food or unhygienic preparation; poultry vaccinated in UK to control spread; symptoms fever, abdominal cramps, vomiting, diarrhoea caused by bacteria and their toxins. Gonorrhoea: STD with thick yellow/green discharge and pain on urination; caused by bacterium; formerly treated with penicillin but resistant strains emerged; spread by sexual contact; controlled by antibiotics and barrier contraception (condom).

Rose black spot: fungal disease with purple/black spots on leaves; leaves may turn yellow and fall early; reduces photosynthesis and plant growth; spread by water/wind; treated with fungicides and/or removal and destruction of affected leaves.
Malaria caused by protist pathogens with life cycle including mosquito vector. Symptoms recurrent fever; can be fatal. Control by preventing mosquito breeding and using mosquito nets to avoid bites.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human defence systems and immune response
Sub_topics.description: Describe non-specific defence systems (barriers): skin, nose, trachea and bronchi, stomach. Explain role of immune system if pathogen enters body. Describe white blood cell actions: phagocytosis, antibody production, antitoxin production.

Explain how vaccination prevents illness in individuals and reduces spread by immunising large proportions of population. Vaccination: introduce small quantities of dead/inactive pathogen to stimulate white blood cells to produce antibodies; on re-exposure rapid antibody production prevents infection. No need for vaccine schedules or specific side effects. Evaluate global use of vaccination for disease prevention.

Explain use of antibiotics and other medicines: antibiotics (e.g., penicillin) cure bacterial disease by killing bacteria; specific bacteria require specific antibiotics. Explain reduced deaths but concern about antibiotic resistance emergence. State antibiotics do not kill viruses. Painkillers/other medicines treat symptoms but do not kill pathogens. Explain difficulty of developing antiviral drugs without damaging body tissues.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Drug discovery and development; trials and peer review
Sub_topics.description: Describe discovery and development of new medicines including preclinical and clinical testing. Traditional extraction from plants/microorganisms: digitalis (foxgloves), aspirin (willow), penicillin (Fleming, Penicillium mould). Most new drugs synthesised; may start from extracted chemical. Testing for toxicity, efficacy and dose: preclinical tests in lab using cells/tissues/live animals; clinical trials on healthy volunteers and patients; very low doses initially; subsequent trials determine optimum dose. Double-blind trials include placebo group. Understand importance of peer review and publication of results.

Recall and use photosynthesis word/symbol equation: carbon dioxide + water → glucose + oxygen (in presence of light). Recognise symbols CO2, H2O, O2 and C6H12O6. Describe photosynthesis as an endothermic reaction transferring energy from environment to chloroplasts by light.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rate of photosynthesis and limiting factors
Sub_topics.description: Explain effects of temperature, light intensity, carbon dioxide concentration and amount of chlorophyll on rate of photosynthesis. Measure and calculate rates; extract and interpret graphs involving one limiting factor; plot/draw appropriate graphs (choose scales); translate between graphical and numeric forms; solve simple algebraic equations where used. (HT) Explain interacting limiting factors using graphs with two/three factors; decide limiting factor. (HT) Use inverse proportion/inverse square law for light intensity in photosynthesis context. (HT) Explain economic importance of limiting factors in greenhouse enhancement (max rate while maintaining profit) and use data to relate cost-effectiveness of adding heat/light/CO2.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Light intensity and photosynthesis rate (pondweed)
Sub_topics.description: Investigate effect of light intensity on rate of photosynthesis using aquatic organism (e.g., pondweed). Measure rate of oxygen production (e.g., bubbles/volume); control temperature using water bath/heat shield; plan method, record data, calculate rates, graph rate vs light intensity, consider repeats and improvements; safe/ethical handling of living organism.

Explain that glucose produced in photosynthesis may be used for respiration; converted to insoluble starch for storage; converted to fats/oils for storage; used to produce cellulose to strengthen cell walls; used to produce amino acids for protein synthesis. State that nitrate ions absorbed from soil are needed to make amino acids/proteins.

Describe cellular respiration as exothermic reaction occurring continuously in living cells; energy transferred supplies energy for living processes (chemical reactions to build larger molecules, movement, keeping warm). Compare aerobic vs anaerobic respiration: oxygen requirement, products, relative energy transferred. Recall/use equations: Aerobic: glucose + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water (recognise C6H12O6, O2, CO2, H2O). Anaerobic in muscles: glucose → lactic acid (less energy due to incomplete oxidation). Anaerobic in plants/yeast: glucose → ethanol + carbon dioxide; fermentation in yeast important for bread and alcohol manufacture.

Explain body response to exercise: increased heart rate, breathing rate, breath volume to supply muscles with more oxygenated blood. If insufficient oxygen, anaerobic respiration occurs; lactic acid builds up causing fatigue; oxygen debt created. (HT) Explain lactic acid transported to liver and converted back to glucose; oxygen debt is extra oxygen needed after exercise to react with accumulated lactic acid and remove it from cells.

Define metabolism as sum of all reactions in a cell/body; explain importance of sugars, amino acids, fatty acids and glycerol in synthesis and breakdown of carbohydrates, proteins and lipids. State that energy transferred by respiration is used for continual enzyme-controlled metabolic processes synthesising new molecules. Include: conversion of glucose to starch, glycogen and cellulose; formation of lipids from glycerol + 3 fatty acids; use of glucose and nitrate ions to form amino acids then proteins; respiration; breakdown of excess proteins to form urea for excretion. Understand as linking ideas across specification.

Explain homeostasis as regulation of internal conditions of a cell/organism to maintain optimum conditions for function in response to internal/external changes; maintains optimal conditions for enzyme action and cell function. In humans includes control of blood glucose concentration, body temperature, and water levels. Control systems may involve nervous or chemical responses. Describe common control system components: receptors detect stimuli; coordination centres (brain, spinal cord, pancreas) receive/process information; effectors (muscles/glands) produce responses restoring optimum levels.

Explain how nervous system structure is adapted to function: receptors detect stimuli; impulses travel along neurones to CNS (brain/spinal cord); CNS coordinates effectors (muscles contract or glands secrete hormones). Use stimulus → receptor → coordinator → effector → response model. Explain reflex arc structures and functions: sensory neurone, synapse, relay neurone, motor neurone; explain importance of reflex actions (automatic, rapid, not involving conscious brain). Extract/interpret data from graphs/charts/tables about nervous system; translate reaction time data between numerical and graphical forms.

Plan and carry out investigation into effect of a factor on human reaction time (e.g., ruler drop or digital test): choose variable, measure time, collect sufficient repeats, present results (tables/graphs), consider accuracy, control variables, ethical/safety considerations, and evaluation of method.

Describe principles of hormonal coordination by endocrine system: glands secrete hormones into bloodstream; blood carries hormone to target organ producing effect; compared with nervous system, hormonal effects slower but longer lasting. Pituitary gland as 'master gland' secreting several hormones in response to body conditions, acting on other glands. Identify positions (on diagram) of: pituitary gland, pancreas, thyroid, adrenal gland, ovary, testes.

Explain blood glucose monitoring and control by pancreas: if too high, pancreas produces insulin causing glucose to move from blood into cells; excess glucose converted to glycogen in liver and muscles. Explain Type 1 diabetes (pancreas fails to produce sufficient insulin; treated with insulin injections) and Type 2 diabetes (cells do not respond to insulin; treated with carbohydrate-controlled diet and exercise; obesity is risk factor). Compare Type 1 vs Type 2 and treatments. Extract/interpret graphs showing effect of insulin on blood glucose in people with and without diabetes. (HT) If blood glucose too low, pancreas produces glucagon converting glycogen to glucose released into blood; explain insulin–glucagon negative feedback cycle controlling glucose.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hormones in reproduction and menstrual cycle
Sub_topics.description: Describe roles of reproductive hormones: during puberty hormones cause secondary sex characteristics. Oestrogen (ovary) main female hormone; eggs mature and one released ~ every 28 days (ovulation). Testosterone (testes) main male hormone; stimulates sperm production. Menstrual cycle hormones: FSH matures egg; LH stimulates egg release; oestrogen and progesterone maintain uterus lining. (HT) Explain interactions of FSH, oestrogen, LH, progesterone in controlling cycle; extract/interpret hormone level graphs across cycle.

Evaluate hormonal and non-hormonal contraception: oral contraceptives inhibit FSH so no eggs mature; progesterone injection/implant/patch inhibits maturation and release of eggs for months/years; barrier methods (condoms, diaphragms) prevent sperm reaching egg; intrauterine devices prevent implantation or release a hormone; spermicides kill/disable sperm; abstaining during fertile window; surgical sterilisation (male/female). Explain that contraception decisions involve social/ethical/economic considerations beyond science; evaluate evidence/arguments and implications.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hormones to treat infertility and IVF (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Explain fertility treatment using hormones: FSH and LH as fertility drugs to stimulate egg maturation/ovulation, enabling pregnancy naturally. Describe IVF: give FSH/LH to stimulate maturation of several eggs; collect eggs and fertilise with sperm in lab; embryos develop; when tiny balls of cells, 1–2 embryos implanted in uterus. Evaluate benefits and risks: emotionally/physically stressful, low success rates, risk of multiple births to babies and mother; understand social/ethical issues; developments in microscopy enabled IVF.

(HT) Explain roles of adrenaline (adrenal glands; fear/stress; increases heart rate and boosts delivery of oxygen and glucose to brain and muscles; 'fight or flight') and thyroxine (thyroid; stimulates basal metabolic rate; important for growth and development). Explain thyroxine control by negative feedback; interpret simple negative feedback diagrams and related data.

Explain that meiosis forms non-identical cells (gametes) whereas mitosis forms identical cells. Describe sexual reproduction as fusion of male and female gametes (animals: sperm and egg; flowering plants: pollen and egg), mixing genetic information producing variation; gametes formed by meiosis. Describe asexual reproduction as one parent, no gamete fusion, no mixing of genetic information, producing genetically identical offspring (clones) via mitosis only. Link to mitosis/cell cycle content.

Explain how meiosis halves chromosome number in gametes and fertilisation restores full number. Describe meiosis outcomes: genetic information copied; cell divides twice to form four gametes each with single set of chromosomes; gametes genetically different. After fertilisation new cell divides by mitosis; embryo develops with increasing cell number and differentiation. Stages of meiosis not required; use models for chromosome behaviour.

Describe DNA structure as polymer of two strands forming double helix; DNA contained in chromosomes. Define gene as small section of DNA coding for a particular amino acid sequence to make a specific protein. Define genome as entire genetic material of an organism. Discuss importance of understanding human genome (limited to: searching for genes linked to disease; understanding and treatment of inherited disorders; tracing human migration patterns).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Genetic inheritance vocabulary and single-gene crosses
Sub_topics.description: Define and use: gamete, chromosome, gene, allele, dominant, recessive, homozygous, heterozygous, genotype, phenotype. Explain single-gene inheritance examples (e.g., mouse fur colour; red-green colour blindness); alleles are different forms of a gene; genotype influences phenotype at molecular level. Dominant allele expressed if one copy present; recessive expressed only with two copies. Homozygous vs heterozygous. Recognise that most characteristics are polygenic (multiple genes). Use probability concept to predict outcomes of single-gene crosses; use direct proportion and simple ratios; complete Punnett squares; interpret genetic crosses and family trees. (HT) Construct genetic crosses using Punnett squares and use probability to make predictions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Inherited disorders and embryo screening ethics
Sub_topics.description: Describe that some disorders are inherited due to specific alleles; examples: polydactyly caused by dominant allele; cystic fibrosis caused by recessive allele (disorder of cell membranes). Make informed judgements about economic, social and ethical issues concerning embryo screening given appropriate information; recognise potential benefits (alleviating suffering) and ethical concerns.

Describe human chromosomes: 23 pairs in body cells; 22 pairs control characteristics; one pair determines sex. Females XX; males XY. Carry out genetic cross to show sex inheritance; use direct proportion and simple ratios in outcomes.

Describe how genome and environment interact to influence phenotype. Define variation as differences in characteristics within a population; causes: genetic (inherited genes), environmental (conditions developed in), or both. State there is usually extensive genetic variation within a population. Recall all variants arise from mutations; most mutations have no phenotypic effect; some influence phenotype; very few determine phenotype. Mutations occur continuously; rarely produce new phenotype; if suited to environmental change can lead to relatively rapid species change.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evolution by natural selection and speciation
Sub_topics.description: Describe evolution as change in inherited characteristics of a population over time through natural selection, potentially forming new species. State theory: all species evolved from simple life forms >3 billion years ago. Explain natural selection: variants arise; those with phenotypes best suited to environment survive/reproduce more, increasing allele frequency. Explain speciation: if two populations become so different they can no longer interbreed to produce fertile offspring, they form two species.

Explain process and impact of selective breeding for desired genetic characteristics: choose parents with desired trait; breed; select offspring with trait; repeat over many generations until trait common in population. Examples: disease resistance in crops; more meat/milk; gentle dogs; large/unusual flowers. Explain risks: inbreeding can increase susceptibility to disease/inherited defects. Evaluate benefits/risks and related ethical issues given information.

Describe genetic engineering as modifying genome by introducing a gene from another organism to give desired characteristic. Examples: GM crops resistant to disease/insect attack/herbicides; increased yields; bacteria engineered to produce useful substances (e.g., human insulin). Explain potential benefits and risks in agriculture and medicine; acknowledge objections. Concerns include effects on wild flower/insect populations and uncertainty about long-term human health impacts from eating GM. (HT) Describe main steps: isolate required gene using enzymes; insert into vector (bacterial plasmid or virus); vector inserts gene into target cells; transfer at early developmental stage so organism develops desired traits. (HT) Interpret information to make informed judgements about cloning/genetic engineering issues including GM crops.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Evidence for evolution (fossils and antibiotic resistance)
Sub_topics.description: Describe evidence for evolution including fossil record and antibiotic resistance in bacteria. Explain that Darwin’s theory is widely accepted; evidence includes genetics (inheritance via genes), fossils, and observed evolution of antibiotic resistance; interpret data supporting evolution.

Define fossils as remains of organisms from millions of years ago found in rocks. Explain fossil formation: parts not decayed due to absent decay conditions; mineral replacement as decay occurs; preserved traces (footprints, burrows, rootlet traces). Explain why fossil record is incomplete (soft-bodied organisms leave few traces; geological activity destroys traces), so origins of life uncertain. Use fossils to learn how organisms changed over time; understand scientific methods/theories develop over time; extract/interpret info from charts/graphs/tables including evolutionary trees.

Define extinction as when no individuals of a species remain alive. Describe factors contributing to extinction (environmental change, new predators, new diseases, competition, catastrophic events, human impacts, etc. as required by context).

Explain rapid bacterial evolution due to fast reproduction; mutations create new strains; resistant strains survive antibiotic treatment, reproduce and increase in frequency; spread as people not immune and treatment ineffective; example MRSA. Explain strategies to reduce resistance: avoid inappropriate prescribing (e.g., for viral/non-serious infections); patients complete full course; restrict agricultural antibiotic use. Explain that developing new antibiotics is costly and slow and may not keep pace with new resistant strains; link to antibiotic use content.

Describe Linnaean classification: kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus, species; binomial naming (genus + species). Use given information to show understanding. Describe impact of developments (microscopy, biochemical understanding) on classification changes. Describe Woese three-domain system based on chemical analysis: Archaea, Bacteria, Eukaryota (includes protists, fungi, plants, animals). Interpret evolutionary trees as showing relationships using current classification and fossil data; understand classification models develop with new evidence.

Describe levels of organisation in an ecosystem from individual organism → population → community → ecosystem; explain importance of interdependence and competition in communities. Define ecosystem as interaction of community (biotic) with abiotic environment. Explain resource requirements for survival/reproduction. Describe plant competition (light, space, water, mineral ions) and animal competition (food, mates, territory). Explain interdependence (food, shelter, pollination, seed dispersal); removal of a species can affect whole community. Define stable community as balance of species and environmental factors with fairly constant population sizes. Record first-hand observations; extract/interpret info from charts/graphs/tables about interactions.

List abiotic factors affecting communities: light intensity, temperature, moisture levels, soil pH and mineral content, wind intensity/direction, carbon dioxide levels (plants), oxygen levels (aquatic animals). Explain how change in an abiotic factor affects a community given data/context; extract/interpret related charts/graphs/tables.

List biotic factors affecting communities: availability of food, new predators, new pathogens, one species outcompeting another so numbers insufficient to breed. Explain how change in biotic factors affects community given data/context; extract/interpret related charts/graphs/tables.

Explain how organisms are adapted (structural, behavioural, functional) to survive in their natural environments given information. Define extremophiles as organisms living in very extreme conditions (high temperature, pressure, salt concentration), e.g., bacteria in deep sea vents.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Food chains, trophic levels and predator–prey cycles
Sub_topics.description: Explain that photosynthetic organisms are producers of biomass for life on Earth. Describe food chains: begin with producer (green plant/alga) synthesising molecules (glucose) by photosynthesis; producers eaten by primary consumers then secondary and tertiary consumers. Define predators and prey; in stable communities predator and prey numbers rise/fall in cycles. Interpret graphs modelling predator–prey cycles. Use ecological sampling methods (transects/quadrats) to determine distribution and abundance; calculate arithmetic means and understand mean/mode/median for abundance data; plot/draw appropriate graphs with appropriate axis scales.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Sampling in a habitat
Sub_topics.description: Measure population size of a common species in a habitat; use sampling techniques (quadrats/transects) to investigate effect of a factor on distribution. Develop hypothesis; choose/justify sampling strategy; measure abiotic factor where relevant; estimate population size from sample; calculate means; present graphs; evaluate sampling reliability and improvements.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cycling of materials: carbon and water cycles; decomposers
Sub_topics.description: Recall that materials cycle through abiotic and biotic components of ecosystems. Explain importance of carbon and water cycles to living organisms. Describe carbon cycle returning carbon as CO2 via respiration of organisms and decomposition; CO2 used by plants in photosynthesis. Describe water cycle providing fresh water on land, continuous evaporation and precipitation, drainage to seas. Students not expected to study nitrogen cycle. Explain role of microorganisms/decomposers in cycling materials: returning carbon as CO2 and mineral ions to soil. Interpret/explain diagrams of carbon and water cycles.

Define biodiversity as variety of different species on Earth or within an ecosystem. Explain that high biodiversity increases ecosystem stability by reducing dependence on single species for food/shelter/maintenance of physical environment. Explain that human future relies on maintaining biodiversity; many human activities reduce biodiversity; measures taken to reduce decline. Explain impacts of waste, deforestation and global warming on biodiversity.

Explain how human population growth and increased living standards increase resource use and waste production; improper handling leads to pollution. Describe pollution types and sources: water (sewage, fertiliser, toxic chemicals), air (smoke, acidic gases), land (landfill, toxic chemicals). Explain that pollution can kill organisms and reduce biodiversity.

Describe how humans reduce land available for other organisms via building, quarrying, farming, dumping waste. Explain peat bog destruction for compost reduces habitat and biodiversity; decay/burning of peat releases CO2. Understand conflicting pressures: cheap compost for food production vs conserving peatlands as habitats and for reducing CO2 emissions; evaluate risks/benefits in context.

Describe reasons for large-scale tropical deforestation: land for cattle and rice fields; crops for biofuels. Evaluate environmental implications of deforestation (biodiversity loss, CO2 changes, habitat destruction, etc.).

Describe biological consequences of global warming; state levels of CO2 and methane increasing contributing to global warming. Understand that scientific consensus on climate change based on systematic reviews of thousands of peer-reviewed publications; explain why evidence may be uncertain/incomplete in complex contexts.

Describe positive and negative human interactions in ecosystems and impacts on biodiversity. Describe measures to maintain biodiversity: breeding programmes for endangered species; protection/regeneration of rare habitats; reintroduction of field margins/hedgerows; reduction of deforestation and CO2 emissions by governments; recycling resources rather than landfill. Evaluate given information about methods tackling human impacts; explain/evaluate conflicting pressures on maintaining biodiversity.

Topics.Topic_name: Atomic structure and the periodic table

Sub_topics.description: State that all substances are made of atoms; an atom is the smallest part of an element that can exist. Use chemical symbols to represent atoms (e.g., O, Na); know there are about 100 elements shown in periodic table. Explain compounds formed from elements by chemical reactions; reactions form new substances and often involve detectable energy change. Explain compounds contain two or more elements chemically combined in fixed proportions; represented by formulae; can only be separated into elements by chemical reactions. Represent reactions by word equations and by symbol equations (balanced). Students should be able to: use names and symbols of first 20 elements, Group 1 and Group 7 elements, and other elements in spec; name compounds from formulae/symbol equations; write word equations; write formulae and balanced chemical equations for reactions in spec. (HT) Write balanced half equations and ionic equations where appropriate.

Define mixture as two or more elements/compounds not chemically combined; chemical properties unchanged. Describe/explain/give examples of separation by physical processes: filtration, crystallisation, simple distillation, fractional distillation, chromatography; no chemical reactions/new substances. Suggest suitable separation/purification techniques for mixtures given information; safe use of separation apparatus.

Explain that new experimental evidence can change/replace scientific models. Describe sequence: atoms as indivisible spheres; discovery of electron → plum pudding model (positive ball with embedded electrons); alpha particle scattering → nuclear model (mass concentrated at charged nucleus) replacing plum pudding; Bohr model with electrons in orbits at specific distances agreeing with observations; later evidence that positive charge subdivided into protons; Chadwick evidence for neutrons ~20 years later. Describe why scattering evidence led to change; differences between plum pudding and nuclear model. Details of Bohr calculations and Chadwick experiments not required; include peer review/communication context.

Recall relative charges: proton +1, neutron 0, electron −1. Explain atoms are neutral because electrons = protons. Define atomic number as number of protons; atoms of same element have same protons; different elements have different protons. Use nuclear model to describe atoms.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Size, mass, isotopes; ions; nuclear notation
Sub_topics.description: Recall atom radius ~0.1 nm (1×10−10 m); nucleus radius ~1×10−14 m (<1/10,000 of atom). Almost all mass in nucleus. Relative masses: proton 1, neutron 1, electron very small. Define mass number as protons + neutrons. Define isotopes as atoms of same element with different neutrons. Use nuclear notation (e.g., 23/11Na) and calculate numbers of protons, neutrons, electrons in atoms/ions given atomic and mass number. Use SI units and nano- prefix; relate atomic scale to physical-world objects; use standard form.
Explain relative atomic mass as weighted average accounting for isotope abundance; calculate Ar given percentage abundances of isotopes.

Explain electrons occupy lowest available energy levels (shells). Represent electronic structure by numbers and by diagrams (e.g., Na 2,8,1). Students may use 'energy levels' or 'shells'. Represent electronic structures of first 20 elements in both forms; link outer shell electrons to periodic table position.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Periodic table: groups, periods and reactivity predictions
Sub_topics.description: Explain elements arranged by atomic (proton) number; columns are groups with similar properties; periodic repetition. Explain elements in same group have same number of outer shell electrons → similar chemical properties. Explain relation between position, electron arrangement and atomic number; predict possible reactions and reactivity from periodic table position.

Describe early tables arranged by atomic weight; incomplete and some mis-groupings; Mendeleev left gaps for undiscovered elements and sometimes changed order; predicted properties later confirmed by discoveries filling gaps; isotopes explain why atomic weight order not always correct. Describe these steps; explain how testing predictions supports/refutes ideas.

Define metals as elements that form positive ions; non-metals do not form positive ions. Describe distribution: metals left/bottom; non-metals right/top. Explain differences between metals and non-metals based on physical/chemical properties; relate to atomic structure and periodic table position; relate reactions to electron arrangement and atomic number.

Describe Group 0 (noble gases) as unreactive due to stable electron arrangements; have full outer shell (8 electrons, except He has 2). Explain boiling points increase down group with increasing relative atomic mass. Explain how properties depend on outer electrons; predict properties from trends.

Describe Group 1 alkali metals with one outer electron and characteristic properties. Describe reactions of first three alkali metals with oxygen, chlorine and water. Explain reactivity increases down group. Explain how properties depend on outer electrons; predict properties from trends.

Describe Group 7 halogens: seven outer electrons; similar reactions; non-metals; diatomic molecules. Describe nature of compounds formed when chlorine, bromine, iodine react with metals and non-metals. Explain trends down group: higher relative molecular mass, melting point and boiling point; reactivity decreases. Explain displacement: more reactive halogen displaces less reactive halogen from aqueous solution of its salt. Explain properties/trends based on outer electrons; predict from trends.

Topics.Topic_name: Bonding, structure, and the properties of matter

Sub_topics.description: Describe three types of strong chemical bond: ionic (electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions), covalent (atoms share pairs of electrons), metallic (atoms share delocalised electrons). State ionic bonding occurs in compounds of metals with non-metals; covalent in non-metal elements and non-metal compounds; metallic in metals and alloys. Explain bonding in terms of electrostatic forces and electron transfer/sharing.

Explain electron transfer in reactions of metals with non-metals: metals lose outer electrons → positive ions; non-metals gain electrons → negative ions; ions formed by Group 1/2 metals and Group 6/7 non-metals achieve noble gas configuration. Represent electron transfer with dot-and-cross diagrams (e.g., NaCl). Draw dot-and-cross diagrams for ionic compounds formed by Group 1/2 metals with Group 6/7 non-metals. Determine ion charges from group number (limited to these groups).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Giant ionic lattices and formulas from models
Sub_topics.description: Describe ionic compounds as giant structures (lattices) held by strong electrostatic attraction in all directions (ionic bonding). Recognise/deduce ionic from structural diagrams; describe limitations of dot-and-cross, ball-and-stick, 2D/3D diagrams for giant ionic structures. Work out empirical formula from a given model/diagram showing ions. Know NaCl structure; others not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Covalent bonding: molecules, polymers, giant covalent
Sub_topics.description: Explain covalent bonding by sharing pairs of electrons; bonds strong. Recognise small-molecule substances from formula; know some covalent substances are polymers (very large molecules) and some are giant covalent structures (diamond, SiO2). Represent covalent bonds using dot-and-cross, line bonds, and diagrams for repeating polymer units (n large). Draw dot-and-cross diagrams for H2, Cl2, O2, N2, HCl, H2O, NH3, CH4. Represent covalent bonding in small molecules, polymers and parts of giant structures with lines for single bonds. Describe limitations of dot-and-cross/ball-and-stick/2D/3D diagrams. Deduce molecular formula from given model/diagram showing atoms/bonds.

Describe metals as giant structures of atoms in regular pattern with delocalised outer electrons free to move through structure. Explain strong metallic bonding due to sharing delocalised electrons; recognise metallic giant structures from bonding diagrams; use 2D/3D representations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: States of matter and particle model (limitations HT)
Sub_topics.description: Describe solids, liquids, gases; melting/freezing at melting point; boiling/condensing at boiling point. Use simple particle model (particles as small solid spheres) to explain state changes; energy required for state changes depends on strength of forces between particles (linked to bonding and structure); stronger forces → higher melting/boiling point. Predict state at different temperatures; explain different temperatures of change of state in terms of energy transfers and bonding; recognise atoms themselves do not have bulk properties. (HT) Explain limitations of simple particle model: no forces shown, all particles spheres, spheres solid.
Use state symbols (s), (l), (g), (aq) in chemical equations; include appropriate state symbols for reactions in the specification.

Explain ionic compounds have high melting/boiling points due to many strong electrostatic attractions in giant lattices. Explain electrical conductivity: conduct when molten or dissolved in water because ions free to move; do not conduct when solid because ions fixed. Structures beyond NaCl not required.

Explain small-molecule substances often gases/liquids with low melting/boiling points due to weak intermolecular forces; melting/boiling overcomes intermolecular forces not covalent bonds. Intermolecular forces increase with molecular size → higher mp/bp for larger molecules. Do not conduct electricity because molecules have no overall charge. Use comparison of weak intermolecular forces vs strong covalent bonds to explain properties.

Explain polymers have very large molecules; atoms joined by strong covalent bonds; intermolecular forces between polymer molecules relatively strong so polymers are solids at room temperature. Recognise polymers from bonding/structure diagrams.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Giant covalent structures: diamond, graphite, silicon dioxide
Sub_topics.description: Explain giant covalent structures are solids with very high melting points because all atoms linked by strong covalent bonds that must be broken to melt/boil. Recognise giant covalent structures from diagrams; examples: diamond, graphite, silicon dioxide.

Explain metals have high melting/boiling points due to strong metallic bonding. Explain pure metals are malleable because atoms arranged in layers; pure metals often too soft; alloys are mixtures of metals harder because different-sized atoms distort layers, preventing them sliding. Explain why alloys are harder than pure metals using this model.
Explain metals conduct electricity because delocalised electrons carry charge; conduct thermal energy because energy transferred by delocalised electrons.

Explain diamond: each carbon forms four covalent bonds in giant covalent structure; very hard, very high melting point, does not conduct electricity. Link properties to bonding/structure; use 2D/3D representations.

Explain graphite: each carbon forms three covalent bonds in layers of hexagonal rings; no covalent bonds between layers; one electron per carbon delocalised. Explain properties (soft/slippery, conducts electricity) by structure and delocalised electrons; note similarity to metals in delocalised electrons.

Describe graphene as single layer of graphite with useful properties for electronics/composites; explain properties by structure/bonding. Describe fullerenes as carbon molecules with hollow shapes based on hexagonal rings plus possible 5- or 7-member rings; example Buckminsterfullerene C60 spherical. Describe carbon nanotubes as cylindrical fullerenes with high length:diameter; uses in nanotechnology, electronics, materials. Recognise graphene/fullerenes from diagrams/descriptions; give examples of uses of fullerenes including nanotubes; link to engineering applications.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Conservation of mass and balancing equations
Sub_topics.description: State law of conservation of mass: no atoms lost/made in chemical reactions; mass of products equals mass of reactants. Explain that symbol equations must be balanced for numbers of atoms of each element. Understand multipliers (coefficients) and subscripts in formulae.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Relative formula mass (Mr) and percentage composition
Sub_topics.description: Calculate relative formula mass (Mr) as sum of relative atomic masses in formula. Explain that in a balanced equation, sum of Mr values of reactants (with coefficients) equals sum for products. Calculate percentage by mass of an element in a compound given Mr and atomic masses.

Explain apparent mass change in open systems due to reactant/product gases not being measured (e.g., metal + oxygen increases mass due to oxygen; thermal decomposition of metal carbonates decreases mass as CO2 escapes leaving metal oxide). Given balanced equation, explain mass changes using particle model; practical contexts of mass measurement with apparatus.
Explain that measurements have uncertainty. Represent distribution of results; estimate uncertainty; use range about mean as a measure of uncertainty.

(HT) Define mole (mol) as unit of amount of substance; mass of 1 mole in grams equals relative formula mass. One mole contains Avogadro constant 6.02×10^23 particles per mole. Apply mole concept to atoms, molecules, ions, electrons and equations (e.g., 1 mol C atoms equals number of molecules in 1 mol CO2). Calculate moles from mass and Mr and vice versa; use standard form, significant figures, and rearrange equations as needed.

(HT) Interpret balanced symbol equations in terms of mole ratios (e.g., Mg + 2HCl → MgCl2 + H2). Calculate masses of substances in a balanced equation; calculate masses of reactants/products from equation and given mass of one reactant/product; use ratios, fractions, percentages; substitute values with correct units.
(HT) Balance equations by converting given masses to moles and finding simplest whole-number ratios; change subject of equations and substitute numerical values with appropriate units.

(HT) Explain use of excess reactant and define limiting reactant as reactant completely used up limiting product amount. Explain effect on product yield in terms of moles or masses; apply to calculations/contexts.

Define concentration as mass of solute per volume of solution (e.g., g/dm^3). Calculate mass of solute in a given volume of solution of known concentration. (HT) Explain relationship between solute mass, solution volume and concentration; rearrange relationships as needed.
Describe metals reacting with oxygen to form metal oxides; identify as oxidation because metal gains oxygen. Explain reduction and oxidation in terms of loss or gain of oxygen.

Explain metals form positive ions in reactions; reactivity relates to tendency to form positive ions. Recall/describe reactions (if any) of K, Na, Li, Ca, Mg, Zn, Fe, Cu with water and dilute acids (room temperature only; no steam) and place in order of reactivity. Include hydrogen and carbon in reactivity series. Explain displacement: more reactive metal displaces less reactive metal from compound; deduce reactivity order from experimental results; relate reactivity to ion formation tendency.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Extraction of metals; reduction by carbon
Sub_topics.description: Explain that unreactive metals may be found native but most metals occur as compounds. Metals less reactive than carbon can be extracted from oxides by reduction with carbon; define reduction as loss of oxygen (limited to carbon reduction of oxides). Interpret/evaluate extraction processes from information; identify oxidised/reduced substances in terms of oxygen gain/loss; details of industrial processes not required.

(HT) Define oxidation as loss of electrons and reduction as gain of electrons. Write ionic equations for displacement reactions; identify species oxidised/reduced in reactions, symbol equations or half-equations.

Describe acids reacting with some metals to produce salts and hydrogen. Reactions limited to Mg, Zn, Fe with hydrochloric and sulfuric acids. (HT) Explain as redox in terms of electron gain/loss; identify oxidised/reduced species in given equations.

Describe neutralisation: acids + alkalis (soluble hydroxides) or bases (insoluble hydroxides/oxides) → salts + water; acids + metal carbonates → salts + water + CO2. Predict products from reactants. Explain salt identity depends on acid (HCl→chlorides; HNO3→nitrates; H2SO4→sulfates) and positive ion in base/alkali/carbonate. Use formulae of common ions to deduce salt formulae.

Describe method to make pure, dry samples of named soluble salts from acids and insoluble solids (metals, metal oxides/hydroxides/carbonates): add excess solid to acid until no more reacts; filter off excess; crystallise salt solution to obtain solid salt. RP8: prepare pure, dry soluble salt from insoluble oxide/carbonate using Bunsen to heat dilute acid and water bath/electric heater to evaporate; include filtration and crystallisation steps; consider safety and purity.

Explain acids produce H+ in aqueous solution; alkalis produce OH− in aqueous solution. Use pH scale (0–14) as measure of acidity/alkalinity; measure using universal indicator or pH probe. pH 7 neutral; acids pH <7; alkalis pH >7. Describe neutralisation in acid-alkali: H+ + OH− → H2O. Describe using indicators to measure approximate pH; identify acidic/alkaline solutions from pH values.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Strong vs weak acids; pH and concentration (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Strong acids completely ionised (HCl, HNO3, H2SO4); weak acids partially ionised (ethanoic, citric, carbonic). For a given concentration, stronger acid has lower pH. Each pH unit decrease corresponds to ×10 increase in [H+]. Distinguish dilute vs concentrated (amount of substance) and weak vs strong (degree of ionisation). Describe neutrality and relative acidity in terms of hydrogen ion concentration and pH (whole numbers); make order-of-magnitude calculations.

Explain electrolysis: molten or aqueous ionic compounds conduct because ions free to move (electrolytes). Passing current causes ions to move to electrodes: cations to cathode (negative), anions to anode (positive); ions discharged to form elements. (HT) Write half equations for electrode reactions; complete/balance supplied half equations.

Describe electrolysis of molten binary ionic compounds with inert electrodes: metal produced at cathode and non-metal at anode (e.g., PbBr2 gives Pb and Br2). Predict products of electrolysis of binary ionic compounds in molten state; recognise safer alternatives may be used in practical (e.g., anhydrous ZnCl2).

Explain electrolysis used to extract metals too reactive for carbon reduction or that react with carbon. Explain energy use for melting and current. Describe aluminium extraction: electrolysis of molten mixture of aluminium oxide and cryolite with carbon anode. Explain why mixture used as electrolyte (to lower melting point) and why positive electrode must be replaced (carbon reacts/consumed).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electrolysis of aqueous solutions; predicting products
Sub_topics.description: Explain products of electrolysis of aqueous solutions using inert electrodes depend on relative reactivity. At cathode: hydrogen produced if metal more reactive than hydrogen. At anode: oxygen produced unless halide ions present, then halogen produced. Explain because water produces H+ and OH− ions that may be discharged. Predict products of electrolysis of aqueous solutions containing a single ionic compound. RP9: investigate electrolysis of aqueous solutions with inert electrodes, developing a hypothesis; observe products and relate to rules.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Half equations and redox at electrodes (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Explain that cathode reactions are reductions (cations gain electrons); anode reactions are oxidations (anions lose electrons). Represent electrode reactions with half equations, e.g., 2H+ + 2e− → H2 and 4OH− → O2 + 2H2O + 4e− (or 4OH− − 4e− → O2 + 2H2O).

Explain energy conservation in chemical reactions: universe energy same before/after; if energy transferred to surroundings, products have less energy than reactants by that amount. Define exothermic as transferring energy to surroundings raising temperature; examples: combustion, many oxidation reactions, neutralisation; uses: self-heating cans, hand warmers. Define endothermic as taking in energy from surroundings lowering temperature; examples: thermal decomposition; citric acid + sodium hydrogencarbonate; uses: sports injury cold packs. Distinguish exothermic/endothermic by surroundings temperature change; evaluate uses/applications given information. Limited to measuring temperature change; no ΔH calculations required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Temperature changes in reactions
Sub_topics.description: Investigate variables affecting temperature changes in reacting solutions (e.g., acid + metals; acid + carbonates; neutralisations; displacement). Measure mass/volume/temperature; plan hypothesis; record and analyse data; consider uncertainty, repeats, control variables; evaluate method.

Explain reactions occur when particles collide with sufficient energy; define activation energy as minimum energy needed to react. Draw simple reaction profiles (energy level diagrams) for exothermic and endothermic reactions: relative energies of reactants/products, activation energy, overall energy change; use curved line vs progress of reaction. Use profiles to identify exothermic/endothermic; explain meaning of activation energy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Bond energies and energy change calculations (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Explain energy must be supplied to break bonds in reactants and released when bonds form in products. Calculate overall energy change using bond energies: sum(bonds broken) − sum(bonds formed). Explain exothermic when energy released by bond formation > energy needed to break bonds; endothermic when energy needed to break bonds > energy released. Perform calculations using supplied bond energies.

Topics.Topic_name: The rate and extent of chemical change

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Rate of reaction calculations and graphs
Sub_topics.description: Calculate mean rate of reaction using quantity of reactant used or product formed over time: mean rate = quantity used/time or quantity formed/time. Quantity measured by mass (g) or volume (cm^3); units g/s or cm^3/s. (HT) Use moles and mol/s. Draw and interpret graphs of quantity of product formed or reactant used vs time. Draw tangents and use slope as rate; (HT) calculate gradient of tangent at a specific time as instantaneous rate. Translate between graphical and numeric forms; use significant figures and estimates.

Recall factors affecting reaction rate: concentration of reactants in solution, pressure of reacting gases, surface area of solid reactants, temperature, presence of catalysts. Describe effect of changing each factor on rate; apply to practical contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Concentration and rate (gas/colour methods)
Sub_topics.description: Investigate how changes in concentration affect rates using two methods: (1) measuring volume of gas produced; (2) measuring colour change or turbidity. Develop hypothesis; plan variables and controls; collect repeat data; graph results; determine slopes/tangents where appropriate; evaluate uncertainties and improvements.

Use collision theory: reactions occur when particles collide with sufficient energy (activation energy). Explain how increasing concentration, pressure (gases), and surface area increases collision frequency → higher rate. Explain increasing temperature increases collision frequency and energy → higher rate. Predict/explain effects of changing concentration, pressure, temperature on rate using collision theory; explain effect of solid piece size via surface area to volume ratio; use simple proportionality reasoning.

Define catalyst as changing rate without being used up; different catalysts for different reactions; enzymes as biological catalysts. Explain catalysts increase rate by providing alternative pathway with lower activation energy; draw reaction profile showing lower activation energy for catalysed reaction. Identify catalysts by effect and absence from chemical equation; explain catalytic action in activation-energy terms; catalyst names not required unless specified.

Define reversible reactions where products can react to form original reactants; represent with ⇌ (A + B ⇌ C + D). Explain direction can be changed by changing conditions; know example ammonium chloride ⇌ ammonia + hydrogen chloride (heated/cooled) as typical.

Explain if reversible reaction exothermic in one direction, endothermic in the other; same energy transferred each way. Use example hydrated copper sulfate ⇌ anhydrous copper sulfate + water (colour changes) as typical representation.
Explain equilibrium in a closed system (no escape of reactants/products) occurs when forward and reverse reactions occur at exactly the same rate; use models/diagrams to interpret.

(HT) Explain that relative amounts of reactants/products at equilibrium depend on conditions; when conditions change, system responds to counteract change. Use Le Chatelier’s Principle to make qualitative predictions about equilibrium shifts given information.

(HT) Predict equilibrium changes when concentration of reactant/product changed: increasing reactant concentration shifts to form more products; decreasing product concentration shifts to form more products until equilibrium restored. Interpret given data to predict effects.

(HT) Predict effect of temperature changes: increasing temperature favours endothermic direction (more products at equilibrium for endothermic forward), decreases products for exothermic forward; decreasing temperature does opposite. Interpret given data to predict effects.

(HT) For gaseous equilibria, increasing pressure shifts equilibrium toward side with fewer molecules (as shown by symbol equation); decreasing pressure shifts toward side with more molecules. Interpret data to predict effects; do not require equilibrium constant calculations.

Describe crude oil as finite resource found in rocks; remains of ancient biomass (mainly plankton) buried in mud. Crude oil is mixture of many compounds; most are hydrocarbons (H and C only). Most hydrocarbons in crude oil are alkanes with general formula CnH2n+2. Name first four alkanes: methane, ethane, propane, butane. Recognise alkanes from molecular formulae and displayed/structural representations; do not need other alkane names.

Explain fractional distillation separates crude oil into fractions with similar carbon chain length by evaporation and condensation. Explain fractions processed to produce fuels and feedstock for petrochemical industry. Know examples of fuels: petrol, diesel, kerosene, heavy fuel oil, liquefied petroleum gases. Know petrochemical products: solvents, lubricants, polymers, detergents. Explain variety of carbon compounds due to ability of carbon to form families of similar compounds; specific names of other fractions not required.

Recall that boiling point, viscosity and flammability depend on hydrocarbon molecule size; recall trends with increasing molecular size. Explain these properties influence fuel uses. Write balanced equations for complete combustion of hydrocarbons given formula, producing CO2 and H2O; describe combustion as oxidation of carbon and hydrogen releasing energy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cracking; alkenes; bromine water test; polymers
Sub_topics.description: Describe cracking as breaking down hydrocarbons to smaller, more useful molecules; methods include catalytic cracking and steam cracking (describe general conditions). Products include alkanes and alkenes. Explain alkenes more reactive; bromine water test: bromine water decolourises (orange/brown to colourless) with alkenes. Explain high demand for small-molecule fuels; cracking produces useful fuels and alkenes used to make polymers and other chemicals. Balance cracking equations given formulae of reactants/products. Give examples illustrating usefulness of cracking and explain modern life’s dependence on hydrocarbons. Students do not need names/formulae of individual alkenes.

Define pure substance in chemistry as single element or compound not mixed with anything else. Explain pure elements/compounds melt/boil at specific temperatures; use melting/boiling point data to distinguish pure substances from mixtures/impure substances. Note everyday meaning of 'pure' may differ (e.g., pure milk).

Define formulation as mixture designed as useful product with measured quantities to achieve desired properties; identify formulations from information. Examples include fuels, cleaning agents, paints, medicines, alloys, fertilisers, foods; names of proprietary components not required; evaluate in application contexts.

Explain chromatography separates mixtures using stationary and mobile phases; separation depends on distribution between phases. Explain paper chromatography and how it distinguishes pure vs impure substances (pure gives single spot in all solvents). Calculate and interpret Rf values: Rf = distance moved by substance (centre of spot from origin) / distance moved by solvent front. Explain different compounds have different Rf in different solvents; use chromatograms to identify substances. RP12: perform paper chromatography on coloured substances and calculate Rf; interpret results with appropriate significant figures.
Describe hydrogen test: burning splint at mouth of test tube; hydrogen burns with squeaky pop.
Describe oxygen test: glowing splint relights in oxygen.
Describe carbon dioxide test: bubble through/shake with limewater (aqueous calcium hydroxide) turns milky/cloudy.
Describe chlorine test: damp litmus paper bleached white.

Recall proportions for last ~200 million years: ~80% nitrogen, ~20% oxygen, small proportions of other gases including carbon dioxide, water vapour, noble gases. Use ratios/fractions/percentages to express composition.

Explain that theories about early atmosphere formation have developed over time; evidence limited due to 4.6 billion year timescale. Describe theory: intense volcanic activity in first billion years released gases forming early atmosphere and water vapour that condensed to oceans; early atmosphere like Mars/Venus today (mainly CO2, little/no O2). Volcanoes produced nitrogen building up; possible small methane and ammonia. Explain CO2 decreased as oceans formed (CO2 dissolved; carbonates precipitated forming sediments). Interpret evidence and evaluate theories given information; recognise uncertainty/limitations.

Explain oxygen in atmosphere produced by algae and plants via photosynthesis: 6CO2 + 6H2O → C6H12O6 + 6O2. State algae produced oxygen ~2.7 billion years ago; oxygen then appeared in atmosphere; over next billion years plants evolved and oxygen increased enabling animals to evolve.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Decrease in carbon dioxide; formation of fossil fuels and limestone
Sub_topics.description: Explain CO2 decreased due to photosynthesis by algae/plants and due to formation of sedimentary rocks and fossil fuels containing carbon. Describe main atmospheric changes over time and likely causes. Describe/explain formation of limestone deposits and fossil fuels (coal, crude oil, natural gas) as carbon stores.

Describe greenhouse gases maintaining Earth temperatures to support life; greenhouse gases include water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane. Describe greenhouse effect in terms of short-wavelength radiation from Sun and long-wavelength infrared radiation re-radiated from Earth interacting with matter in atmosphere.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Human activities increasing greenhouse gases; evidence quality
Sub_topics.description: Recall two human activities that increase CO2 and two that increase methane (e.g., burning fossil fuels/deforestation for CO2; livestock/rice paddies/landfill for methane). Explain many scientists (peer-reviewed evidence) believe human activity increases average temperature leading to climate change, but complex models lead to uncertainty and possible media bias. Evaluate quality of evidence in reports given information; describe uncertainties; recognise importance of peer review and communicating results.

Explain increase in average global temperature as major cause of climate change. Describe briefly four potential effects (e.g., sea level rise, changing rainfall, extreme weather, habitat shifts, biodiversity impacts). Discuss scale, risk and environmental implications of global climate change.

Define carbon footprint as total CO2 and other greenhouse gases emitted over full life cycle of product/service/event. Describe actions to reduce emissions of CO2 and methane; explain why actions may be limited (economic, practical, political, etc.).

Explain combustion of fuels as major source of atmospheric pollutants; fuels contain C/H and may contain sulfur. Describe gases released: CO2, water vapour; also CO (from incomplete combustion), SO2 (from sulfur impurities), oxides of nitrogen NOx (from high-temperature air), particulates/soot and unburned hydrocarbons. Describe how CO, soot, SO2, NOx produced; predict products of combustion given fuel composition and conditions.

Explain properties/effects: carbon monoxide is toxic, colourless/odourless; sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides cause respiratory problems and acid rain; particulates cause global dimming and health problems. Describe/explain problems caused by increased pollutant levels.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Earth’s resources; finite vs renewable; sustainable development
Sub_topics.description: Describe how humans use Earth’s resources for warmth, shelter, food, transport. Explain natural resources supplemented by agriculture provide food, timber, clothing, fuels. Explain finite resources from Earth/oceans/atmosphere processed for energy/materials. Define sustainable development as meeting current needs without compromising future generations. Give examples of natural products supplemented/replaced by agricultural/synthetic products; distinguish finite vs renewable resources given info. Extract/interpret resource information from charts/graphs/tables and use orders of magnitude to evaluate data significance.

Explain potable water is safe to drink with low levels of dissolved salts and microbes; not pure water chemically because contains dissolved substances. Describe UK potable water production from fresh water (rain → ground/lakes/rivers): choose source, filter beds, sterilise (chlorine, ozone or UV). If fresh water limited, desalination of sea/salty water by distillation or reverse osmosis (membranes); requires lots of energy. Distinguish potable vs pure; compare ground water vs salty water treatment; explain reasons for steps. RP13: analyse and purify water samples from different sources including pH, dissolved solids and distillation; sampling considerations and evaluation.

Describe need to treat sewage/agricultural/industrial waste water before release; remove organic matter and harmful microbes/chemicals. Describe sewage treatment stages: screening and grit removal; sedimentation producing sewage sludge and effluent; anaerobic digestion of sludge; aerobic biological treatment of effluent. Comment on relative ease of obtaining potable water from waste vs ground vs salt water.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alternative metal extraction: phytomining and bioleaching (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Explain metal ore resources limited; copper ores scarce. Describe extracting copper from low-grade ores by phytomining (plants absorb metal compounds; harvest and burn to ash containing metal compounds) and bioleaching (bacteria produce leachate with metal compounds). Explain obtaining metal from solutions by displacement with scrap iron or by electrolysis. Evaluate alternative biological extraction methods given information.

Describe LCA as assessing environmental impact of products across stages: raw material extraction/processing; manufacturing/packaging; use/operation; disposal including transport/distribution. Explain some impacts (water, resources, energy, some wastes) can be quantified, but pollutant effects involve value judgements so LCA not purely objective. Explain selective/abbreviated LCAs can be misused to support pre-determined conclusions (e.g., advertising). Carry out simple comparative LCAs (e.g., plastic vs paper shopping bags) and interpret given LCAs; quantify where data available (energy, water, resources, wastes).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reduce, reuse, recycle; evaluating resource use
Sub_topics.description: Explain reduction, reuse and recycling by end users reduces use of limited resources, energy, waste and environmental impacts. Describe that metals, glass, building materials, clay ceramics and most plastics come from limited raw materials; energy often from limited resources; quarrying/mining impacts environment. Describe reuse (e.g., glass bottles) and recycling (glass crushed and remelted; metals melted/recast/reformed). Explain separation needs depend on material and desired properties; example: adding scrap steel to blast furnace reduces iron extraction from ore. Evaluate ways of reducing use of limited resources given information.

Define system as object or group of objects; describe that energy is stored in different stores and changes in storage occur when system changes. Describe energy changes for common situations: object projected upward; moving object hitting obstacle; object accelerated by constant force; vehicle slowing down; bringing water to boil in electric kettle. Calculate energy changes when system changed by heating, by work done by forces, and by work done when a current flows; use calculations to show redistribution of energy on a common scale; apply energy conservation ideas.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kinetic, elastic potential and gravitational potential energy
Sub_topics.description: Calculate energy associated with moving objects, stretched springs and raised objects using equations: Ek = 1/2 m v^2; Ee = 1/2 k e^2 (within limit of proportionality); Ep = m g h (g given). Use correct units: J, kg, m/s, N/m, m, N/kg. Recognise/apply equations and relate to energy transfers (e.g., GPE to KE).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Specific heat capacity and thermal energy change
Sub_topics.description: Calculate change in thermal energy using ΔE = m c Δθ. Define specific heat capacity as energy required to raise temperature of 1 kg by 1°C. Use J, kg, J/kg°C, °C. Apply equation to heating contexts.

Determine specific heat capacity of one or more materials by linking decrease of one energy store (or work done) to temperature rise and increase in thermal energy stored. Measure mass, time, temperature; calculate energy (e.g., from electrical power Pt) and ΔE; evaluate accuracy, precision, repeatability, uncertainties, heat losses; present and analyse data.
Define power as rate of energy transfer or work done. Use equations: P = E/t and P = W/t. Units: watt (W) = joule per second. Compare devices by power for same work/energy in different times.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Energy conservation, dissipation and thermal conductivity
Sub_topics.description: State energy cannot be created/destroyed; can be transferred usefully, stored or dissipated. Describe energy transfers in a closed system with no net change in total energy. Explain dissipation (wasted energy) stored in less useful ways. Explain reducing unwanted transfers via lubrication and thermal insulation.
