Relate rate of energy transfer by conduction to thermal conductivity; describe how cooling rate of building affected by wall thickness and thermal conductivity (definition of thermal conductivity not required).

Calculate efficiency using: efficiency = useful output energy transfer / total input energy transfer; or efficiency = useful power output / total power input. Express as decimal or percentage. (HT) Describe ways to increase efficiency of intended energy transfer; evaluate in contexts.

Describe main energy resources: fossil fuels (coal, oil, gas), nuclear fuel, bio-fuel, wind, hydro-electricity, geothermal, tides, Sun, water waves. Define renewable vs non-renewable; compare uses (transport, electricity generation, heating). Explain reliability differences among resources. Describe environmental impacts of different resources and patterns/trends in resource use. Evaluate that science can identify issues but solutions involve political/social/ethical/economic considerations; interpret charts/graphs about resource use.

Use standard circuit diagram symbols; draw and interpret circuit diagrams for common components (cell, battery, lamp, resistor, variable resistor, thermistor, LDR, diode, LED, fuse, switch, ammeter, voltmeter, etc.).

Explain current as rate of flow of charge; for charge to flow, closed circuit must include a source of potential difference. Use equation Q = I t (charge flow = current × time) with units C, A, s. State current has same value at any point in a single closed loop.

Explain current through component depends on resistance and potential difference across it; higher resistance gives smaller current for given pd. Use term potential difference (voltage acceptable). Use equation V = I R with units V, A, Ω. RP15 links: set up circuits to investigate resistance factors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Resistance in series/parallel and wire length
Sub_topics.description: Use circuit diagrams to set up and check circuits investigating factors affecting resistance: (1) length of wire at constant temperature; (2) combinations of resistors in series and parallel. Measure V and I, compute R; plot graphs (e.g., R vs length); evaluate method, control temperature, repeats, uncertainty.

Explain that for some resistors R constant; others change with current. Ohmic conductor at constant temperature: I directly proportional to V (linear I–V), resistance constant. Non-ohmic components: filament lamp resistance increases with temperature/current; diode conducts in one direction only with very high reverse resistance; thermistor resistance decreases as temperature increases (applications e.g., thermostat); LDR resistance decreases as light intensity increases (applications e.g., automatic lights). Design circuits to measure resistance by measuring I and V; draw circuit diagrams with correct symbols. Use graphs to identify linear vs non-linear behaviour and relate curve shapes to component properties.

Construct circuits to investigate I–V characteristics of filament lamp, diode and resistor at constant temperature. Measure current and potential difference; plot I–V graphs; identify linear/non-linear regions; evaluate uncertainties and control variables.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Series and parallel circuits (rules and calculations)
Sub_topics.description: Describe series and parallel connections, including mixed circuits. Series: same current through each component; supply potential difference shared; total resistance equals sum: R_total = R1 + R2. Parallel: same potential difference across each branch; total current is sum of branch currents; total resistance less than smallest branch resistor (calculation of parallel equivalent resistance not required). Use circuit diagrams to construct/check circuits; explain qualitatively why series increases resistance and parallel decreases. Calculate currents, potential differences and resistances in dc series circuits; solve problems using equivalent resistance in series.
Explain difference between direct and alternating potential difference. State UK mains electricity is ac, ~230 V, 50 Hz.

Describe three-core cable wiring: live (brown), neutral (blue), earth (green/yellow). Live carries alternating pd; neutral completes circuit; earth is safety wire preventing appliance casing becoming live; earth at 0 V; neutral at/near 0 V; pd between live and earth ~230 V. Explain why live wire dangerous even when switch open; explain dangers of connection between live and earth; evaluate risk in domestic contexts.
Explain power transfer in devices related to V and I and to energy changes over time. Use equations: P = V I and P = I^2 R. Use correct units; apply to calculations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Energy transfer in appliances; electrical work
Sub_topics.description: Describe that appliances transfer energy; energy depends on power and time. Describe energy transfers from batteries/ac mains to kinetic energy in motors or heating devices. Use equations: E = P t and E = Q V for electrical work/energy transferred. Explain relationship between appliance power ratings and changes in stored energy when used; use examples.

Describe National Grid as system of cables and transformers linking power stations to consumers. Explain power transferred using high pd: step-up transformers increase pd for transmission; step-down decreases for domestic use. Explain why Grid is efficient (reduced current for given power reduces energy loss in cables). (HT) Use transformer power equation Vp Ip = Vs Is (from equation sheet) to solve problems; detailed transformer structure not required.

Define density ρ = m/V with units kg/m^3, kg, m^3. Apply to changes where mass conserved; use standard form where appropriate. Use particle model to explain differences between solids, liquids and gases and differences in density in terms of particle arrangement. Recognise/draw simple particle diagrams for states.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Density of solids and liquids
Sub_topics.description: Determine densities of regular and irregular solids and liquids. Measure mass and volume: regular solids by dimensions (ruler, micrometer, Vernier calipers) and volume calculations; irregular solids by displacement; liquids by measuring volume. Record measurements with appropriate units and significant figures; calculate density; evaluate uncertainties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Changes of state and conservation of mass
Sub_topics.description: Describe that mass is conserved during changes of state (melting, freezing, boiling, evaporating, condensing, sublimation). Explain changes of state are physical changes (reversible, material recovers properties), unlike chemical changes.

Define internal energy as total kinetic and potential energy of particles in a system. Explain heating increases internal energy by increasing particle energy, raising temperature and/or causing change of state.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Temperature change and specific heat capacity (physics)
Sub_topics.description: Apply ΔE = m c Δθ to calculate energy changes when temperature changes. Explain temperature rise depends on mass, material and energy input; define specific heat capacity as energy to raise 1 kg by 1°C; distinguish from latent heat.

Explain latent heat as energy needed to change state without temperature change; define specific latent heat as energy to change state of 1 kg with no temperature change. Use equation E = m L with units J, kg, J/kg. Distinguish latent heat of fusion vs vaporisation. Interpret heating and cooling graphs including plateaus at changes of state; distinguish specific heat capacity vs specific latent heat.

Describe gas molecules in constant random motion; temperature related to average kinetic energy. Explain qualitatively how changing temperature of gas at constant volume changes pressure, linking to particle motion and collision frequency/force.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Atomic structure and electron energy levels
Sub_topics.description: Recall atom radius ~1×10−10 m; nucleus positively charged with protons and neutrons; electrons negative in energy levels. Nucleus radius <1/10,000 of atom; most mass in nucleus. Explain electrons can change energy levels by absorbing/emitting electromagnetic radiation; relate to model of atom; use standard form.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mass number, atomic number, isotopes and ions
Sub_topics.description: Define atomic number as number of protons; mass number as protons + neutrons. Explain neutral atoms have electrons = protons; isotopes differ in neutron number. Explain atoms become positive ions by losing one or more outer electrons. Relate isotope differences to conventional representations (identity, charge, mass).

As in chemistry: describe evidence-driven model changes from indivisible sphere → electron discovery → plum pudding → alpha scattering → nuclear model → Bohr energy levels → proton and neutron discovery. Explain why scattering led to change and differences between plum pudding and nuclear model; details not required.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Radioactive decay and nuclear radiation types
Sub_topics.description: Explain some nuclei unstable and emit radiation to become more stable; radioactive decay is random. Define activity as rate of decay (Bq) and count-rate as decays recorded per second. Describe nuclear radiation types: alpha (α) 2p+2n (helium nucleus), beta (β) high-speed electron from nucleus as neutron turns into proton, gamma (γ) electromagnetic radiation from nucleus, neutron (n). Required properties limited to penetration through materials, range in air and ionising power. Apply knowledge to uses of radiation and evaluate best sources for situations; consider risk.

Use nuclear equations for decay. Represent α as 4/2He and β as 0/−1e. Explain effect of emissions on mass number and atomic number: alpha decreases both; beta leaves mass same but increases atomic number by 1; gamma causes no change. Write balanced equations for single alpha and beta decay by balancing atomic and mass numbers; identification of daughter elements not required.

Define half-life as time for number of nuclei in sample to halve or for count rate/activity to fall to half. Explain half-life related to random nature of decay. Determine half-life from given data/graphs. (HT) Calculate net decline as a ratio after a given number of half-lives.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Irradiation vs contamination; precautions; peer review
Sub_topics.description: Define radioactive contamination as unwanted presence of radioactive material on objects; hazard due to decay; type of radiation affects hazard. Define irradiation as exposure to radiation; irradiated object does not become radioactive. Compare hazards of contamination vs irradiation; describe need for precautions to protect from sources. Explain importance of publishing/sharing findings about radiation effects and peer review.
Define scalar quantities as magnitude only; vector quantities as magnitude with direction. Represent vectors with arrows: length magnitude, arrow direction is vector direction.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Contact and non-contact forces; interaction pairs
Sub_topics.description: Define force as push/pull due to interaction between objects; forces are contact (friction, air resistance, tension, normal contact) or non-contact (gravitational, electrostatic, magnetic). Force is a vector. Describe interaction between pairs of objects producing forces on each; represent forces as vectors.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weight, mass and gravitational field strength
Sub_topics.description: Define weight as force due to gravity; gravitational field strength varies with location. Use equation W = m g with units N, kg, N/kg (g given). Explain weight acts at centre of mass. Explain weight and mass directly proportional; weight measured using calibrated spring-balance (newtonmeter); use proportionality symbol ∝.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Resultant forces and free body diagrams (HT components)
Sub_topics.description: Define resultant force as single force having same effect as all forces combined. Calculate resultant of two forces in a straight line. (HT) Describe forces on isolated objects/systems; use free body diagrams for multiple forces leading to resultant, including balanced forces (resultant = 0). (HT) Resolve a single force into two perpendicular components; use vector diagrams (scale drawings) to resolve forces, show equilibrium and determine resultant of two forces including magnitude and direction.

Explain work is done when a force causes displacement. Use equation W = F s (distance moved along line of action). Units: J, N, m; 1 J = 1 N m. Describe energy transfer when work is done. Convert between N m and J. Explain work done against friction causes temperature rise.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Forces and elasticity; Hooke’s law; spring energy
Sub_topics.description: Give examples of forces in stretching, bending, compressing. Explain that changing shape of stationary object requires more than one force. Distinguish elastic vs inelastic deformation. State extension/compression proportional to force for elastic objects up to limit of proportionality: F = k e. Describe linear vs non-linear force-extension; calculate spring constant for linear; interpret force-extension data. Calculate work done in stretching/compressing a spring (up to limit) and elastic potential energy: Ee = 1/2 k e^2; explain work done equals energy stored if no inelastic deformation.

Investigate relationship between force and extension for a spring: measure force (weights/newtons) and extension; plot force-extension graph; identify limit of proportionality; calculate spring constant; evaluate method, uncertainty, repeats and anomalies.

Define distance as how far object moves (scalar). Define displacement as distance moved in a straight line from start to finish plus direction (vector). Express displacement with magnitude and direction; use unit conversions and proportional reasoning.

Define speed as scalar; explain speed often varies. Recall typical speeds: walking ~1.5 m/s, running ~3 m/s, cycling ~6 m/s; typical sound speed in air ~330 m/s; recall typical values for transport systems in context. Measure distance and time to calculate speed. Use equation s = v t for constant speed; calculate average speed for non-uniform motion.

Define velocity as speed in a given direction (vector). Explain vector-scalar distinctions for displacement/distance and velocity/speed. (HT) Explain qualitatively that circular motion can have constant speed but changing velocity (direction changes).

Use distance–time graphs for straight-line motion; calculate speed from gradient. (HT) For acceleration, determine speed at a time by tangent gradient. Draw graphs from measurements; interpret slopes and translate between graphical and numerical forms.

Calculate average acceleration using a = Δv / t. Estimate everyday accelerations. Determine acceleration from gradient of velocity–time graph. (HT) Determine distance/displacement from area under velocity–time graph; measure area by counting squares when appropriate. Use uniform acceleration equation v^2 − u^2 = 2 a s (given). Recall free-fall acceleration ~9.8 m/s^2. Explain terminal velocity: falling object in fluid accelerates then reaches zero resultant force and constant terminal velocity.

Apply Newton’s First Law: if resultant force is zero, stationary objects remain stationary; moving objects continue at same speed and direction (constant velocity). Explain steady-speed vehicle: resistive forces balance driving force. Conclude velocity changes only if resultant force acts. (HT) Define inertia as tendency to continue in state of rest or uniform motion; apply concept qualitatively.

Explain acceleration proportional to resultant force and inversely proportional to mass; use equation F = m a. Estimate speeds, accelerations and forces in everyday road transport; use approximate symbol ~. (HT) Explain inertial mass as measure of difficulty changing velocity and defined as F/a (ratio).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required practical: Force, mass and acceleration
Sub_topics.description: Investigate effect of varying force on acceleration for constant mass and effect of varying mass on acceleration for constant force. Use motion measurement apparatus (e.g., light gates/data loggers/ticker timers). Record length/mass/time; calculate acceleration; plot graphs; evaluate uncertainty, repeatability and control variables.

State Newton’s Third Law: when two objects interact, forces they exert are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. Apply to examples including equilibrium situations and interactions (e.g., recoil, collisions, pushing).
Define stopping distance as thinking distance + braking distance. Explain for given braking force, higher speed gives greater stopping distance; interpret and apply in safety contexts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reaction time and thinking distance factors
Sub_topics.description: State typical reaction times 0.2–0.9 s; explain effects of tiredness, drugs, alcohol, distractions on reaction time and thinking distance. Explain methods to measure reaction time; interpret/evaluate measurements and data; evaluate effects of factors on thinking distance.

Explain braking distance affected by adverse road/weather (wet/icy) and poor vehicle condition (brakes/tyres). Explain implications for safety; estimate how stopping distance varies with speed using given data and proportional reasoning.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Braking forces, work done and deceleration dangers
Sub_topics.description: Explain braking: friction does work reducing kinetic energy; brakes heat up. Explain higher speed requires greater braking force to stop in same distance; greater braking force gives greater deceleration; large decelerations can cause overheating and/or loss of control; evaluate risk. (HT) Estimate forces involved in typical decelerations on public road.

(HT) Define momentum p = m v with units kg m/s. Explain conservation of momentum: in closed system total momentum before equals total momentum after. Use momentum as model to describe/explain events such as collisions; interpret experimental data; use calculations in one dimension.

Distinguish transverse vs longitudinal waves. Give examples: water surface ripples are transverse; sound in air is longitudinal with compressions and rarefactions. Describe evidence that waves transfer energy without bulk movement of medium (water/air particles oscillate).

Describe amplitude (maximum displacement), wavelength (distance between equivalent points), frequency (waves per second), period T = 1/f, wave speed as speed of energy transfer. Use wave equation v = f λ with units m/s, Hz, m. Identify amplitude and wavelength from diagrams. Describe methods to measure speed of sound in air and speed of ripples on water; plan measurements with suitable apparatus and evaluate method.

Make observations to identify suitability of apparatus to measure frequency, wavelength and speed of waves in a ripple tank and waves in a solid; take appropriate measurements; calculate wave speed using v = fλ; record units and significant figures; evaluate measurement uncertainty and method limitations.

Explain electromagnetic waves are transverse and transfer energy from source to absorber; all EM waves travel at same speed in vacuum/air. Describe EM spectrum groups in order of wavelength/frequency: radio, microwave, infrared, visible (red to violet), ultraviolet, X-rays, gamma rays. State eyes detect only visible. Give examples illustrating energy transfer by EM waves.

(HT) Explain absorption, transmission, refraction and reflection can vary with wavelength and substance. Explain refraction due to change in wave speed between media. Construct ray diagrams for refraction at boundary. Use wavefront diagrams to explain refraction via speed change.

Investigate how amount of infrared radiation absorbed or radiated by a surface depends on nature of surface (e.g., matt black vs shiny). Measure temperature changes; control variables; record data with units/significant figures; present results (e.g., bar charts); evaluate uncertainties.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: EM waves, oscillations and ionising radiation risks
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Explain radio waves can be produced by oscillations in electrical circuits; absorption can induce alternating current of same frequency (induce oscillations). Explain EM waves generated/absorbed by changes in atoms/nuclei; gamma rays from nuclear changes. Explain ultraviolet, X-rays and gamma rays can be hazardous; effects depend on type and dose. Radiation dose (sieverts) measures risk of harm; 1000 mSv = 1 Sv; unit recall not required. Use given data to draw conclusions about risks and consequences of exposure. Explain UV causes skin ageing and increases skin cancer risk; X-rays and gamma are ionising, can mutate genes and cause cancer.

Describe practical applications: radio (TV/radio), microwaves (satellite comms, cooking), infrared (heaters, cooking, IR cameras), visible light (fibre optics), ultraviolet (energy efficient lamps, sun tanning), X-rays/gamma (medical imaging/treatments). (HT) Give brief explanations for suitability of each type for application (penetration, frequency, energy, communication properties, etc.).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic poles; permanent vs induced magnetism
Sub_topics.description: Describe magnet poles as regions of strongest force; like poles repel, unlike attract (non-contact force). Define permanent magnet as producing its own magnetic field. Define induced magnet as material becoming magnetised in external field; induced magnetism causes attraction only; induced magnet loses magnetism quickly when removed. Describe differences between permanent and induced magnets.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magnetic fields and compasses; Earth’s field
Sub_topics.description: Define magnetic field as region around magnet where force acts on another magnet or magnetic material (iron, steel, cobalt, nickel). Force between magnet and magnetic material always attraction. Field strength decreases with distance; strongest at poles. Define field direction as direction of force on a north pole; field lines go from north-seeking to south-seeking pole. Describe how to plot field with compass; draw bar magnet field showing direction and relative strength. Explain compass behaviour as evidence Earth’s core must be magnetic; relate needle direction to Earth’s magnetic field.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Electromagnetism: fields around currents and solenoids
Sub_topics.description: Explain current in wire produces magnetic field; field strength depends on current and distance. Describe solenoid increases field strength; field inside solenoid strong and uniform; field pattern like bar magnet. Explain iron core increases solenoid field strength; electromagnet = solenoid + iron core. Demonstrate magnetic effect of current; draw field patterns for straight wire and solenoid including direction; explain how solenoid increases magnetic effect.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Motor effect and Fleming’s left-hand rule (HT)
Sub_topics.description: (HT) Describe motor effect: force on conductor carrying current in magnetic field; magnet and conductor exert equal and opposite forces. Use Fleming’s left-hand rule to relate force direction, current direction and field direction. Recall factors affecting force size. Use equation for conductor at right angles: F = B I l (force in N; flux density B in tesla; current A; length m).
(HT) Explain that a coil of wire carrying current in magnetic field tends to rotate; basis of electric motor. Explain how forces on opposite sides of coil cause rotation.
